docs.lead_paragraph: ''Saving Your Brain,'' by Dr. Jeff Victoroff, Bantam Books, $25.95. ''Bodily decay is gloomy in prospect,'' Thomas Jefferson observed, ''but of all human contemplations the most abhorrent is body without mind.'' True enough, but while one may readily entertain such a gloomy thought, there are, this author says, some things we can do to keep our brains fit, our minds alert and our defenses against memory loss boosted. Written by a neurologist/neuropsychiatrist at the University of Southern California, the book offers a number of steps to fight against the decline of brain function.
docs.abstract: John Langone reviews book Saving Your Brain by Dr Jeff Victoroff; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Prescription drug abuse among anesthesiologists, who have access to some of the most powerful and addictive medications in a hospital, remains a problem, despite increased prevention efforts, a new study reports. The study, reported in this month's issue of Anesthesia and Analgesia, is based on a survey of 123 academic medical centers. They reported that in the 1990's, 1 percent of their anesthesiology faculty members and 1.6 percent of their residents had drug problems.

headline.main: Doctors With Keys to the Cabinet

docs.abstract: Duke University study led by Dr John V Booth, published in journal Anesthesia and Analgesia, concludes that prescription drug abuse among anesthesiologists remains problem despite increased prevention efforts; drawing (M)
